perturbation.original_text: 1.7 Relationship of Parties. The relationship between the Company and the Distributor Page -3- is that of vendor and vendee. This Agreement does not create the relationship of principal and agent between the Company and the Distributor for any purpose whatsoever.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.7 Relationship of Parties. The relationship between the Company and the Distributor Page -3- is that of vendor and vendee. This Agreement shall create the relationship of principal and agent between the Company and the Distributor for specific purposes outlined in Section 2.5.
perturbation.explanation: By stating that the agreement *does* create a principal-agent relationship for specific purposes, we introduce a contradiction and ambiguity. This is misaligned because traditionally, a distributor agreement intends vendor/vendee relationship, where a distributor is an independent entity buying and selling products, rather than acting as an agent on behalf of the company. Creating a principal-agent relationship, even for limited purposes, introduces legal complexities and potential liabilities.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Agency Law - specifically concerning the duties and liabilities of principals and agents.
perturbation.law_explanation: The changed text contradicts the common understanding and legal framework surrounding distributor agreements, which generally avoid creating a principal-agent relationship. Illinois law defines agency and the duties that accompany it; creating such a relationship, even for limited purposes, can invoke these duties and liabilities which are not desired in a typical distributor relationship. The alteration creates uncertainty as to the scope of the agency relationship and potential fiduciary duties.

( ) 765 ILCS 1045/1 (765 ILCS 1045/1) (from Ch. 140, par. 101) Sec. 1. This Act may be cited as the Industrial and Linen Supplies Marking Law. (Source: P.A. 86-1475.) 765 ILCS 1045/2 (765 ILCS 1045/2) (from Ch. 140, par. 102) Sec. 2. For the purposes of this Act, unless otherwise required by the context: (a) "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership or corporation. (b) "Name," "mark," or "device" means any word, name, symbol, picture, design or device, or any combination thereof, produced upon, and used by a person to indicate ownership of articles and supplies as herein defined. (c) "Produced upon" means branded, transferred, stamped, stenciled, engraved, etched, blown, embossed, impressed, embroidered, sewn, or otherwise permanently placed upon any articles or supplies referred to herein. (d) "Articles" or "Supplies" means, but is not limited to, any item which is designed or intended for loan or other compensated use and re-use in the normal course of trade by the person filing hereunder, and includes but is not limited to towels, industrial wiping towels, sheets, pillow cases, napkins, tablecloths, linen, coats, aprons, garments serviced by linen and towel supply companies, garments serviced by industrial garment and towel supply companies, articles of dust control, toilet devices, towel dispensing cabinets or other kindred articles or supplies such as bags, carts, baskets or other receptacles used as packages or containers in the loaning or other circulation of such articles or supplies. (e) A name, mark or device is "used in this State" when such name, mark or device is placed upon articles or supplies which are loaned, rented or otherwise circulated within the State. (f) "Registrant" means any person who files a name, mark or device under this Act. (Source: Laws 1967, p. 1405.) 765 ILCS 1045/3 (765 ILCS 1045/3) (from Ch. 140, par. 103) Sec. 3. Right to register name or mark. Any person who uses in this State a name, mark or device to indicate ownership of articles or sup

perturbation.original_text: 3.3 Warranty. Company shall at all times make reasonable efforts to maintain quality control and to deliver Products to Distributor which, when received by Distributor, or, as the case may be, the end-user, are properly and adequately packaged and contained, fully assembled (except for miscellaneous components which may be shipped separately to prevent damage in transit), fully functional and otherwise in conformance with the warranties set forth herein. Company warrants that the Products will be designed, manufactured, constructed, assembled and packaged in a workmanlike manner and that such Products shall be fully functional and fit for their intended purposes. Company further warrants that the Products sold hereunder shall be free from defects in design, materials and workmanship for a period of twenty-four (24) months after delivery to Distributor's end-user. The Company shall not be liable for defective Products, except as provided in this Agreement. The Distributor at all times shall comply with all requirements of the Magnuson-Moss Warranty-Federal Trade Commission Improvement Act and similar federal and state laws and regulations.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.3 Warranty. Company shall at all times make reasonable efforts to maintain quality control and to deliver Products to Distributor which, when received by Distributor, or, as the case may be, the end-user, are properly and adequately packaged and contained, fully assembled (except for miscellaneous components which may be shipped separately to prevent damage in transit), fully functional and otherwise in conformance with the warranties set forth herein. Company warrants that the Products will be designed, manufactured, constructed, assembled and packaged in a workmanlike manner and that such Products shall be fully functional and fit for their intended purposes. Company warrants that the Products will be designed, manufactured, constructed, assembled and packaged in an ordinary manner and that such Products shall be functional and seemingly fit for their usual general purposes. Company further warrants that the Products sold hereunder shall be free from defects in design, materials and workmanship for a period of one (1) month after delivery to Distributor's end-user. The Company shall not be liable for defective Products, except as provided in this Agreement. The Distributor at all times shall comply with all requirements of the Magnuson-Moss Warranty-Federal Trade Commission Improvement Act and similar federal and state laws and regulations.
perturbation.explanation: The original text uses "workmanlike manner". I replaced this with "ordinary manner" to introduce legal ambiguity, and similarly for "fit for their intended purposes" becoming "seemingly fit for their usual general purposes". Further, the warranty was reduced to 1 month. By using "ordinary manner" and "usual general purposes", the warranty obligation of the company is reduced. The warranty period has also been reduced to one month. Illinois has specific provisions regarding implied warranties and their disclaimers. By reducing the warranty period and altering the language of the warranty, the agreement now attempts to reduce the protections afforded to the distributor, potentially contradicting Illinois warranty law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Uniform Commercial Code - Implied Warranty of Merchantability
perturbation.law_explanation: Illinois law provides an implied warranty of merchantability, which requires that goods be fit for the ordinary purposes for which such goods are used. By warranting only that products are designed, manufactured, and packaged in an 'ordinary manner' and are 'seemingly fit for their usual general purposes,' the modified text attempts to weaken this implied warranty. Additionally, the shorter warranty duration conflicts with what is considered a reasonable time for discovering defects, potentially rendering the disclaimer unconscionable under Illinois law.

perturbation.original_text: 2.7 Payment Terms. Distributor shall pay Company within thirty (30) days of Distributor's or, as the case may be, the end-user's receipt of Products.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.7 Payment Terms. Distributor shall pay Company within ninety (90) days of Distributor's acceptance of the products, regardless of the end-user's receipt of Products. Distributor acceptance is assumed upon completion of 30 days, following delivery, if there is no written notice of defects.
perturbation.explanation: Payment terms were changed from 30 to 90 days and acceptance is tied to a 30-day notification of defects. This change attempts to alter the standard commercial transaction terms and payment deadlines for goods. While parties can contractually agree to payment terms, imposing a 90-day payment window, especially when acceptance is presumed after 30 days unless defects are reported, can contradict standard business practices and potentially violate requirements of good faith and fair dealing. Further, a 90 day payment term may conflict with other laws related to debt collection or prompt payment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Sales Representative Act - specifically concerning timely payment to sales representatives.
perturbation.law_explanation: While this Act primarily covers sales representatives, the principle of timely payment can be extended to distributor agreements if the distributor is considered a sales representative under the law. Illinois law mandates timely payment to sales representatives after termination of the agreement. Extending payment terms to 90 days, especially with presumed acceptance after 30 days, could be seen as an attempt to circumvent these timely payment requirements and create an unreasonable delay in compensation. If the distributor is deemed a sales representative under Illinois law, this change could be considered a violation.

EMPLOYMENT (820 ILCS 250/) Underground Sewer Employee Safety Act. 820 ILCS 250/0.01 (820 ILCS 250/0.01) (from Ch. 48, par. 1100) Sec. 0.01. Short title. This Act may be cited as the Underground Sewer Employee Safety Act. (Source: P.A. 86-1324.) 820 ILCS 250/0.05 (820 ILCS 250/0.05) Sec. 0.05. Federal regulations; operation of Act. (a) Except as provided in subsection (b), Sections 1 through 6 of this Act are inoperative on and after the effective date of this amendatory Act of the 102nd General Assembly. (b) If at any time the Occupational Safety and Health standards at 29 CFR 1910.120, 29 CFR 1910.146 or the Safety and Health Regulations for Construction standards 29 CFR 1926.1201 through 29 CFR 1926.1213 are repealed or revoked, the Director of Labor shall adopt a rule setting forth a determination that this Act should be reviewed and reinstated, in whole or in part, in order to protect the health and safety of Illinois' workers. On the date such a rule is adopted, this Act shall again become operative. (Source: P.A. 102-1071, eff. 6-10-22.) 820 ILCS 250/1 (820 ILCS 250/1) (from Ch. 48, par. 1101) Sec. 1. This Act shall apply to all employers engaged in any occupation, business or enterprise in this State, including the State of Illinois and its political subdivisions. (Source: P.A. 102-1071, eff. 6-10-22.) 820 ILCS 250/2 (820 ILCS 250/2) (from Ch. 48, par. 1102) Sec. 2. It shall be the duty of every employer to furnish each employee who performs duties which involve or may reasonably be expected to involve entering an underground sewer, including but not limited to such employees as utility workers, firemen, policemen, paramedics, investigators and personnel involved with maintenance and repair work, information concerning the prevention of personal injuries and diseases by contact with poisonous or deleterious materials, vapors, gases or fumes. (Source: P.A. 81-772.) 820 ILCS 250/3 (820 ILCS 250/3) (from Ch. 48, par. 1103) Sec. 3. It shall be the duty of every employer of any person performing construction, maintenance or repair work inside any underground sewer which has been used as such to have safety information and equipment available at the work site. Such information and equipment shall include at a minimum (i) material for use as lifelines, (ii) equipment for venting of locations in the underground sewers where work is to be performed, (iii) individual oxygen masks or similar gear for each employee who works underground, (iv) chemicals or equipment to test for dangerous gas, and (v) equipment for prompt communications with emergency m
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: Illinois Statutes Chapter 820. Employment § 120/2 | FindLaw Illinois Statutes Chapter 820. Employment § 120/2. Commissions Current as of January 01, 2022 | Updated by FindLaw Staff § 2. All commissions due at the time of termination of a contract between a sales representative and principal shall be paid within 13 days of termination, and commissions that become due after termination shall be paid within 13 days of the date on which such commissions become due. Any provision in any contract between a sales representative and principal purporting to waive any of the provisions of this Act shall be void.
